p: Among the various fungal pathogens that affect humans, Candida albicans is the major fungus that is frequently associated with Candidiasis, causing a mortality rate up to 50% [ 2, 3]. Humans are a natural reservoir for C. albicans, which colonizes on the mucosal surfaces (oral, GI, and urogenital tracts) and can disseminate systemically by their yeast-to-hypha conversion, leading to life-threatening invasive fungal infections. Other species of Candida ( C. glabrata, C. krusei) also contribute significant infections that are intrinsically resistant to fluconazole [ 4]. An emerging Candida fungal pathogen, C. auris, is a major concern due to its pan-antifungal resistance, persistence in hospital environments as well as its invasive virulence potential with a high mortality rate (60%) [ 5, 6].
